Fig. 1 XRD patterns (a) and crystal size in (131) direction of the calcined catalysts with various Co/Al ratio (b). Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) XPS spectra of the calcined catalysts with various Co/Al ratio. (b) The Co3+ fraction as a function of Co/(Co + Al) ratio for the calcined catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles (a) and reduction degree (b) of the calcined catalysts with various Co/(Co + Al) ratio. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) H2-TPD profiles and (b) H2 uptake with the percentage of weakly adsorbed H in reduced catalysts with varying Co/(Co + Al) ratios. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) CO2-TPD profiles and (b) CO2 uptake in reduced catalysts with varying Co/(Co + Al) ratios. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Product yields. The experiments were conducted in a batch reactor with 15 mL of H2O as the solvent, using 50 mg of catalyst under conditions of 3 MPa H2, 1 MPa CO2, at 180 °C, with magnetic stirring at 350 rpm for 1 h. Error bars are based on three independent measurements. (b) Y MeOH-Y CH4 correlation. (c) Y EtOH-Y CH4 correlation. (d) Y EtOH-Y MeOH correlation. The lines are only for visual guidance. Fig 6 Fig. 7 TOFs for methanol, ethanol, and methane formation over the reduced catalysts with various Co/(Co + Al) ratio. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Microscopic analysis of Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R catalyst. (a-c) TEM images showcasing the morphology; (d) HAADF-STEM image highlighting structural details; (e) Elemental mapping of Al and Co; (f) Combined HAADF-STEM image with overlaid elemental mapping of Al and Co. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Time on stream in situ DRIFT spectra over Co0.5Al0.5Ox-R (a) and Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R (b), as well as their spectrum at 280 °C (c) of CO2 hydrogenation under 1 MPa CO2 and 3 MPa H2. (a) is reprinted with permission from Ref. [27]. Fig 9 Fig. 10 CO2 hydrogenation mechanism over Co based catalysts. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [27]. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Proposed mechanism for the enhanced CO2 hydrogenation and ethanol formation over reverse catalyst. Reaction intermediate over Co0.5Al0.5Ox-R (a), Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R (b), and CoOx-R. authors have contributed equally Inverse catalysts, characterized by their distinctive interfaces, demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity for CO2 conversion. This study explores the synthesis of an Al-Co oxide/Co0 inverse catalyst through the reduction of a Co-Al oxide with a high Co content, achieved by modulating the Co/Al ratio in the oxide precursor. The resulting inverse catalyst significantly enhances CO2 hydrogenation, yielding increased production of methane, methanol, and ethanol, with a notable amplification in ethanol output. Amongst, the catalyst with a Co/Al ratio of 9:1 achieves high yields for methane (32,131 μmol/g, methanol (461 μmol/g), and ethanol (123 μmol/g). To elucidate the structure and reaction mechanism, the inverse catalyst was also characterized using a suite of techniques. It is posited that the abundance of active sites on the inverse catalyst, coupled with its moderate H binding affinity, facilitates CO2 activation and conversion. This is particularly evident in the enhanced coupling of *HCOO and *CH3 intermediates, which promotes ethanol synthesis. This research not only sheds light on the interactions between metal and metal oxide within Co-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation but also proposes a facile method for crafting efficient catalysts for such processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Inverse catalyst Cobalt Interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating levels of greenhouse gases, particularly carbon dioxide (CO2), in the atmosphere pose a significant threat to the sustainable development of human society. Addressing CO2 emissions is now central to the development of technologies aimed at mitigating global warming. As potential alternatives Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU) technologies have emerged as a promising solution, converting CO2 into useful fuels and chemicals [1]. This not only helps in reducing CO2 emissions but also generates additional value. A key process in this technology is the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which involves reacting CO2 with green hydrogen to produce various products [2–5]. Recent studies have extensively examined the thermodynamics of CO2 hydrogenation and its potential to reduce CO2 emissions [6–10]. Furthermore, the efficiency of this reaction heavily relies on catalysts, making their role crucial in effective CO2 hydrogenation. The development of catalysts like Cu–ZnO–Al2O3, In2O3/ZrO2, ZnO–ZrO2, In2O3/HZSM-5, Fe–Cu/Al2O3, Na–Fe3O4/HZSM-5, and Pt/Co3O4 has significantly advanced the synthesis of methanol, light olefins, long-chain hydrocarbons, gasoline, and higher alcohols [2,11–16]. Additionally, a range of strategies, including the engineering of defects, morphology, phase, support, as well as promoter addition, and inverse supporting, have been employed to enhance the activity and selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation [17–21]. Notably, the inverse supporting strategy, which involves supporting metal oxide on a metal, differs from methods commonly employed in traditional supported catalysts. This approach has gained widespread use in CO2 hydrogenation, delivering outstanding performance [21]. The exceptional performance in CO2 hydrogenation is often attributed to the unique interface present in inverse catalysts, influencing the formation and conversion of the intermediates. Wu et al. demonstrated that an inverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst, with zirconia on metallic Cu particles, outperformed the conventional Cu/ZrO2 catalyst in converting CO2 to methanol [22]. In the inverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst, the ZrO2 species were highly reduced, facilitating the rapid formation and consumption of formate and methoxy intermediates, compared to the Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. This high activity is primarily due to the formation of a highly reactive HCOOCu intermediate on the metallic Cu of the inverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst. Additionally, Xu et al. explored an inverse ZrZnOx/Cu catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation [23]. This catalyst increases the number of weak and medium CO2 adsorption sites, which were found to be crucial for methanol productivity. The inverse interface in this catalyst promotes the reduction of asymmetric formate intermediates and inhibits the production of CO, enhancing both CO2 activation and the hydrogenation rate of intermediates, leading to remarkable methanol synthesis performance. The inverse supporting strategy can also affect the metal particle size and further influence the overall catalytic performance. Wang et al. found that the unique inverse structure in a ZnO/Cu catalyst prevents the formation of highly dispersed Cu sites, consequently reducing CO production [24]. This results in the ZnO/Cu catalyst achieving an impressive methanol yield of 2.8 mmol/g/h. In contrast, research by Zou et al. on an inverse ZnO-ZrO2 Cu catalyst revealed that ZnO primarily serves as a spacer, promoting the formation of smaller Cu crystals [25]. This leads to an increase in the active Cu surface area and enhances the interactions between ZnO and Cu and ZrO2 phases. However, increasing the ZnO content in this configuration causes this phase to agglomerate, forming a structure more akin to a traditional supported catalyst. This agglomeration hinders the effective interaction, potentially limiting the catalyst's efficiency. Cobalt (Co)-based catalysts are highly versatile in CO2 hydrogenation, capable of producing methane, methanol, higher alcohols, lower olefins, and longer hydrocarbons. This versatility is attributed to the presence of various Co active sites, such as Co0, CoO, and Co2C [26,27]. The interaction between Co0 and CoO has been previously identified as crucial for CO2 hydrogenation [27]. As discussed earlier, inverse catalysts can create unique interfaces/interactions, which are critically important for CO2 hydrogenation. An Al oxide/Co° catalyst has proven effective for Fischer–Tropsch CO hydrogenation [28]. The inverse catalyst significantly reduces methane selectivity while increasing the selectivity for the desired C5+ products. These changes in activity and selectivity are attributed to increased surface carbon coverage as the Al content rises. This effect is likely due to the enhanced CO dissociation facilitated by Lewis acid sites associated with Al islands on the catalytically active material. However, there has been a notable gap in studies concerning inverse cobalt-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. In this study, a novel Al-Co oxide/Co0 inverse catalyst was designed using a co-precipitation method, with meticulous adjustment of the Co/Al ratio, followed by a reduction in H2. This obtained inverse catalyst demonstrates a distinctive interaction between metal and metal oxide, which significantly boosts CO2 hydrogenation and ethanol synthesis. The observed enhancement is attributed to the abundance of active sites and the formation of moderately bound H. This research sheds new light on the interactions between metal and metal oxide in Co-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation and presents a facile strategy for developing highly efficient catalysts for the process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis CoAl mixed hydroxides were prepared through a modified co-precipitation technique based on an established method [27]. This involved preparing two solutions: Solution A, containing Al(NO3)3 and Co(NO3)2 with a total metal concentration of 0.12 M (with Co/Al ratios of 1:9, 3:7, 5:5, 7:3, 9:1, and 10:0), and Solution B, containing 0.40 M NaOH and 0.12 M Na2CO3. These were concurrently added to an ice-cold beaker under steady stirring, ensuring a constant pH of 8.5. The resulting mixture was then filtered, and the precipitate was washed with deionized water to eliminate impurities. Subsequently, the product was dried at 100 °C and underwent air calcination at 400 °C for 3 h, followed by a 3-hour H2 reduction at 650 °C where applicable. The final catalysts were designated as Co m Al n Ox-R, indicating the Co/Al ratios (m/n) and reduction (R) stages. Notably, the characterization and catalytic results of Co0.5Al0.5Ox have been previously reported in our earlier paper, which discusses the Co0-Co2+ synergy in CO2 hydrogenation [27]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Characterization of the synthesized catalysts involved various techniques. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a SmartLab diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and Scherrer equation was applied to determine crystallite sizes. N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K were performed using a Micromeritics 2460 instrument. For the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, a Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer was utilized, calibrating binding energies against the Al 2p peak at 74.6 eV. Co and Al contents were quantified by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a Varian 720ES. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a FEI Talos F200S 200 kV electron microscope, and the energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) with the elemental mapping was obtained by Super FEI-X EDS detector. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) techniques, were employed to study the catalysts’ reducibility as well as their capability to activate H2 and CO2, using a VDSorb-9Xi chemisorption analyzer, in line with the methodology outlined in Ref. [12]. Initially, the catalysts were dried at 150 °C for 1 hour under an Ar atmosphere. In H2-TPR tests, they were exposed to a 10 % H2/Ar mixture with a flow rate of 30 mL/min, heating at a rate of 10 °C/min from 70 to 800 °C, and then held at the final temperature for 10 min. For H2-TPD, the catalysts were first reduced in hydrogen at 650 °C for 3 h. After reducing the temperature to 100 °C under Ar for 30 min, they were exposed to 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min) for 1 hour to allow H2 adsorption. This was followed by argon purging for 1 hour and a subsequent desorption process from 100 to 800 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min over 50 min. In CO2-TPD experiments, following a similar reduction process, the samples were cooled to 50 °C under Ar. Then CO2 adsorption was performed at 50 °C for 1 hour in a 5 % CO2/He mixture, followed by He purging for 1 hour and CO2 desorption under the same temperature conditions as H2-TPD. Throughout these experiments, a thermal conductivity detector is used to track the changes in composition of the gas stream. The reduction degree (RD) and dispersion (D) were quantified using Eqs. (1)–2. RD (%), representing the extent of reduction, was calculated from the ratio of reduced cobalt (n Co,red, μmol/g) to total cobalt (n Co,tot, μmol/g). D (%) was determined from the ratio of surface-exposed reduced cobalt (n Co,red,surf, μmol/g) to total reduced cobalt (n Co,red, μmol/g). These calculations were based on H2 consumption/uptake during H2-TPR/TPD. In the quantification of n Co,red and n Co,tot, the reduction peaks below approximately (330–450 °C) correspond to the transformation of Co3O4 into metallic Co, with the consumption of 1 mol of H2 yielding ¾ mol of Co0. In contrast, peaks observed above (330–450 °C) are associated with the reduction of CoO and CoAl2O4 to Co0, where 1 mol of H2 produces 1 mol of Co0. The volume of chemisorbed H2 was used to estimate n Co,red,surf, under the assumption of dissociative adsorption of hydrogen. (1) R D = n Co , red n Co , tot × 100 % (2) D = n Co , red , surf n Co , red × 100 % 2.3 Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy measurements The setup for diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) entails employing a Nicolet IS50 spectrometer with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector, along with a Harrick Praying Mantis™ diffuse reflectance accessory that includes a high-temperature reaction chamber. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were reduced under H2 at 650 °C for 3 h. Following reduction, the catalysts were loaded into the chamber and purged with Ar. Subsequently, the chamber was heated to 180 °C under Ar flow, and the pressure within was increased to 4 MPa. A mixture of CO2/H2 (12.5/37.5 mL/min) was then introduced to initiate the hydrogenation reaction, with temperatures gradually elevated to 230 and then 280 °C. DRIFT spectra were continuously recorded using 128 scans and a resolution of 8 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic tests CO2 hydrogenation tests adhered to previously established protocols (Ref. [27]). A 50 mL batch reactor, equipped with a magnetic stirrer and Teflon lining, was loaded with 50 mg of pre-reduced catalyst and 15 mL water. The reactor was purged three times with 1 MPa CO2, then pressurized with an additional 1 MPa CO2 and 3 MPa H2. The mixture was heated to 180 °C, stirred at 350 rpm for 1 hour, and subsequently cooled. Gaseous products were analyzed offline using an Agilent 8890 GC system (equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, a HayeSep Q column, and a MolSleve 5 A column), and CH4 concentration was determined using the external standard method. The liquid phase was examined using an Agilent 8860 GC system (equipped with a flame ionization detector and an HP-Innowax column). Tetrahydrofuran served as the internal standard for quantification purposes. Methanol, ethanol, and methane yields (Y, μmol/g), along with their turnover frequencies (TOF, 1/h), were calculated using Eqs. (3) and 4, (3) Y i = n i m cat (4) T O F i = n i t × n C o , r e d , s u r f × m cat in which, i = methanol, ethanol, or methane, n i (μmol, carbon based) represents the moles of the product, t (h) represents the reaction time, and m cat (g) represents the catalyst mass. 3 Results and discussions The catalysts underwent a series of physical and chemical characterizations to elucidate their structure. The elemental composition of the calcined catalysts was determined using ICP-OES (Table 1 ). This analysis reveals that the Co/(Co + Al) molar ratios are 0.10, 0.30, 0.52, 0.70, 0.90, and 1.00, aligning with nominal values used during the synthesis. Furthermore, the textural properties of the calcined catalysts were examined through N2 physisorption studies (Figure S1). As presented in Table 1, the specific surface area of the catalysts initially increases with an increasing Co/(Co + Al) ratio, peaking at 190 m2/g for a ratio of 0.30. However, a further increase in the Co/(Co + Al) ratio results in a decrease in specific surface area. The crystal structure of the calcined catalysts was examined using X-ray diffraction (XRD). Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the emergence of peaks corresponding to the (111), (022), (131), (040), (242), (151), and (044) reflections of the spinel structure [29,30]. These peaks are indicative of the formation of CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4, and Co3O4. Notably, an increase in the Co/(Co + Al) ratio leads to a more pronounced intensity of these peaks, suggesting enhanced crystallinity of the materials. This enhancement in crystallinity implies that excess Al oxides may be present in an amorphous phase. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 1(b), the crystal size for the (131) index increases from 2.9 to 19.2 nm as the Co/(Co + Al) ratio increases from 0.1 to 1.0, further corroborating the increase in crystallinity. The detailed view of the (131) peak, shown in Figure S2, reveals a shift towards lower 2θ angles. This shift could be attributed to the formation of different species as the Co/(Co + Al) ratio increases. The progression from CoAl2O4 to Co2AlO4 and subsequently to Co3O4 is associated with an increase in lattice parameters and d-spacing [31], which accounts for the observed lower shift in the XRD peaks. XPS was used to study the oxidation state of Co in the calcined catalysts. The resulting Co 2p spectra are depicted in Fig. 2 . The spectra distinctly show the Co 2p peaks, which are linked to the 1/2 and 2/3 orbitals. These peaks are indicative of low spin Co3+ located in the octahedral positions and high spin Co2+ situated in the tetrahedral positions within the spinel formations of CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4, and Co3O4 [32]. Accompanying satellite peaks are also observed in these spectra. Moreover, the Co3+ fraction in the calcined catalysts increases with increasing Co/(Co + Al) ratio (Fig. 2b), align with the transformation of CoAl2O4 to Co2AlO4 and subsequently Co3O4. H2-TPR was utilized to examine the reduction behavior of the calcined catalysts with varying Co/Al ratios. The H2-TPR profiles are depicted in Fig. 3 . The catalyst Co0.1Al0.9Ox exhibits relatively weak reduction peaks, attributable to its low Co content. In contrast, the CoOx catalyst, lacking Al, displays a characteristic reduction profile of Co3O4 [33]. The overlapping peaks observed are attributed to the sequential reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and then to metallic Co0. For catalysts with Co/(Co + Al) ratios ranging from 0.3 to 0.7, two distinct sets of reduction peaks are observed. The first set, appearing at lower temperatures between 150 and 450 °C, corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4. The second set, occurring at higher temperatures ranging from 450 to 800 °C, is associated with the reduction of Co species that strongly interact with Al, such as CoAl2O4 and Co2AlO4 [34]. Notably, the intensity of the second peak relative to the first increases with the Co/(Co + Al) ratio, suggesting an augmented formation of CoAl2O4 and Co2AlO4 [35]. In the case of Co0.9Al0.1Ox, a notable shift of the second peak towards lower temperatures was observed, potentially due to the transformation of CoAl2O4 to Co2AlO4 at higher Co/(Co + Al) ratios, as supported by XPS results. This shift can be attributed to the higher reducibility of Co2AlO4 compared to CoAl2O4 [35]. The obtained reduction degrees are also presented in Fig. 3b. The Co0.1Al0.9Ox catalyst shows a reduction degree of 28 %, while catalysts with Co/(Co + Al) ratios of 0.3–0.7 exhibit reduction degrees between 57 %−60 %. Increasing the Co/(Co + Al) ratio to 0.9 results in a reduction degree of 95 %, and for CoOx, the reduction degree reaches 100 %. H2-TPD was employed to assess the H2 activation capability of the reduced catalysts. The H2-TPD profiles for these catalysts, varying in Co/(Co + Al) ratios, are presented in Fig. 4 a. Additionally, Fig. 4b demonstrates the correlation between H2 uptake and the proportion of weakly adsorbed H as a function of the Co/(Co + Al) ratio. Notably, two distinct sets of desorption peaks are evident: the lower temperature peak (below 600 °C) corresponds to weakly adsorbed H, while the higher temperature peak (above 600 °C) indicates the presence of strongly adsorbed H [36,37]. An interesting observation is that the H2 uptake initially increases, reaching a maximum of 331.4 µmol H2/gcat at a Co/(Co + Al) ratio of 0.5. However, a further increase in this ratio results in a decline in H2 uptake. In cases where aluminum is absent, the H2 uptake significantly decreases to 5.9 µmol H2/gcat. This finding aligns with Dong's research, which suggests that unsupported Co nanoparticles exhibit a low capacity for H2 adsorption [38]. Furthermore, an increase in the Co/(Co + Al) ratio appears to weaken the H adsorption strength of the catalysts. This is evidenced by a shift to lower temperature in the desorption of weakly adsorbed hydrogen and an increase in its fraction. The underlying cause is attributed to the interaction between Co and the support material. Prior studies have indicated that H2 activation is enhanced with a stronger metal-support interaction [39]. Moreover, the increasing particle size with increasing Co/(Co + Al) ratio may also partially contribute to the decreasing H2 uptake. CO2 TPD was utilized to investigate the activation of CO2 over reduced catalysts with varying Co/(Co + Al) ratios. Fig. 5 presents the CO2-TPD profiles alongside the corresponding CO2 uptake data. Accordingly, two primary sets of CO2 desorption peaks are observed: the lower temperature peak (below 570 °C) is attributed to the desorption of weakly adsorbed CO2, whereas the higher temperature peak (above 570 °C) is associated with the desorption of strongly adsorbed CO2. A key observation is that as the Co/(Co + Al) ratio increases, the high-temperature desorption peak becomes less pronounced and eventually vanishes when the ratio exceeds 0.7. Additionally, there is a consistent decrease in CO2 uptake with increasing Co/(Co + Al) ratio. Specifically, as the ratio rises from 0.1 to 1.0, the CO2 uptake declines sharply from 1038.6 to 2.2 μmol/g. Generally, it's considered that CO2 adsorption occurs at room temperature on metal oxide surfaces, while at temperatures below 0 °C, it occurs on metal surfaces [40]. Therefore, these desorption peaks are likely indicative of CO2 adsorbed on Co oxide surfaces. Moreover, the diminishing CO2 uptake with an increasing Co fraction can be attributed to a higher degree of reduction in the catalyst together with a decreasing fraction of the Co oxides. Besides, the increase in crystallite size accompanying the rise in Co fraction also partially contributes to the observed decrease in CO2 uptake. The catalytic performance of reduced catalysts with varying Co/(Co + Al) ratios was assessed for CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 6 a). The CO2 hydrogenation over these catalysts predominantly yielded methane, with methanol and ethanol also being produced. An increase in the Co proportion initially leads to higher yields for all three products, peaking at 32,131.3 μmol/gcat for methane, 460.8 μmol/gcat for methanol, and 123.5 μmol/gcat for ethanol. However, at a Co/(Co + Al) ratio of 1, there is a significant decrease in the yields of all products. Beyond activity, catalyst stability is crucial for practical applications. However, studying stability in a batch reactor inevitably exposes the catalyst to air during recycling, which can lead to oxidation and unreliable stability data. To obtain reliable stability information for practical use, further studies should be conducted using a flow reactor.The study also examined the correlations between the yields of methanol, ethanol, and methane (Fig. 6b-d). It is observed that the yield of methanol increases linearly with the increasing yield of methane. In the case of ethanol, the yield of ethanol initially shows a linear increase with the increasing yield of methane and methanol. However, an anomaly is noted for the Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R catalyst, which demonstrates the highest product yield. In this instance, the yield of ethanol deviates from the linear correlation, resulting in higher values than expected. This deviation could potentially be attributed to the unique morphology and structural characteristics of the Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R catalyst. Furthermore, the TOFs for methanol, ethanol, and methane production over reduced catalysts with different Co/(Co + Al) ratios were calculated (Fig. 7 ). Initially, a slight increase in the TOFs for all three products is observed as the Co proportion rises from 0.1 to 0.7. Notably, a more pronounced increase occurs when the Co proportion further increases from 0.7 to 0.9. In this range, the TOFs for methanol, ethanol, and methane escalate markedly, showing enhancements of 4.7, 5.6, and 4.0 times, respectively. This significant increase underscores the exceptional catalytic efficiency of the Co0.9Al0.1Ox composition for CO2 hydrogenation. However, an additional increase in the Co proportion, particularly in the absence of Al, resulted in a decrease in the TOFs for all products. This trend indicates that while a higher Co content up to a certain level improves catalytic performance, an imbalance caused by the complete absence of Al adversely affects the efficiency of the catalysts in facilitating these reactions. To elucidate the remarkable catalytic efficiency of the Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R catalyst, its morphology and structure were examined through microscopic analysis. Fig. 8 reveals that the catalyst exhibits spherical particles. Notably, lattice fringes are discernible within the central region of these particles, with a d-spacing of 0.205 nm, aligning with the (111) facet of face-centered cubic (fcc) Co0 [41]. Additionally, amorphous structures are evident at the particle edges. Elemental mapping provides further insights, indicating a concentration of Al at the peripheries of the spherical particles. This observation suggests the formation of an ‘inverse catalyst’ structure, wherein Al oxide appears to be support on the surface of Co0. This unique inverse structure, coupled with the resultant metal-metal oxide interaction, is pivotal in driving the exceptional catalytic performance of Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R. Even though Co0.7Al0.3Ox-R shows the presence of Al species on the surface of Co0, aggregation of these Al species is observed (Figure S3). This aggregation is believed to be the primary reason for the reduced activity, highlighting the importance of Al species’ size as a critical factor for the inverse catalyst's performance. Thus, a low Al/Co ratio should be used to ensure the small size of the Al species. This ratio, however, is dependent on the synthesis method. Finally, in situ DRIFTS measurements were conducted to elucidate the mechanism of enhanced CO2 hydrogenation over the inverse supported Al-Co oxide/Co° catalysts (Fig. 9 ). Under CO2 hydrogenation conditions, the in situ DRIFT spectra of the reduced catalyst with a Co/(Co + Al) ratio of 0.5 reveal absorption bands corresponding to the reactant, intermediate, and some products. Notably, adsorbed/gas phase CO2 (3596, 3729, 3700, 2310, 2328 cm−1) [42–45], *CO (2077, 2128, 1933 cm−1) [46–48], *HCOO (2886, 2888, 1372, 1435 cm−1), *CH3O (2821, 1032, 1056 cm−1) [49–51], CH4 gas (3014, 1305 cm−1) [52,53], *CH3COO (1456, 1436, 1418, 1542 cm−1) [54–57], and *CH3CH2O (1473 cm−1) [58] were also observed. Based on prior studies, the *HCOO intermediate plays a pivotal role in CO2 hydrogenation over Co-Al based catalysts, potentially hydrogenating to CH3OH or CH4 (Fig. 10 ) [27,59]. Furthermore, a coupling reaction between *CHx and *HCOO, followed by hydrogenation, may lead to the formation of ethoxy species and ethanol [27]. The IR bands corresponding to these species were also observed over the reverse catalyst (Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R), with enhanced intensity for various intermediates and products. Specifically, the enhanced formation of *HCOO aligns with the increased CO2 hydrogenation rate supported by catalytic results. Notably, a band ascribed to *CH3 (1342 cm−1) was observed over the reverse catalyst [60], promoting the *HCOO-*CH3 coupling step. Consequently, the formation of C2 O-containing species, *CH3CH2O, and *CH3COO, is enhanced, leading to increased ethanol formation, as evidenced by the deviation of ethanol yield from the linear correlation of Y EtOH-Y MeOH/CH4. Based on the findings regarding the catalysts’ structure and catalytic performance, a plausible mechanism is proposed to elucidate the enhancement of CO2 hydrogenation and ethanol formation over the reverse supported catalyst (Fig. 11 ). The normal catalysts, such as Co0.5Al0.5Ox-R, comprise a mixture of Co0 and CoO supported on Al oxide, which provides abundant active sites for the activation of H2 and CO2, resulting in the formation of various intermediates, as corroborated by H2/CO2-TPD results and in situ DRIFTS. The catalyst's surface exhibits a predominance of strongly adsorbed H over moderately adsorbed H, which hinders the diffusion and spillover of H, thereby reducing the formation of intermediates such as *HCOO and consequently lowering the CO2 reaction rate [61,62]. In contrast, the reverse supported catalyst (Co0.9Al0.1Ox-R) features fewer active sites for H2 and CO2 activation compared to Co0.5Al0.5Ox-R, as indicated by the H2-TPD and CO2-TPD results. The reduction in active sites may be attributed to the increased crystallite size (as suggested by XRD) and the higher reduction degree (as evidenced by H2-TPR). On the contrary, the reverse supported Al-Co oxide/Co0 structure offers specific sites for moderate H adsorption, facilitating H diffusion and spillover. This promotes the formation of intermediates such as *HCOO and *CH3, as well as the *HCOO-*CH3 coupling step, thereby increasing the CO2 hydrogenation rate, particularly promoting ethanol formation. For catalysts without aluminum (i.e., completely reduced Co0), very few active sites are available for CO2 and H2 activation due to the large crystallite size (as suggested by XRD) and the absence of Co-metal oxide interaction (100 % reduction degree as evidenced by H2-TPR), resulting in a very low CO2 hydrogenation rate. 4 Conclusion In this research, a straightforward approach of Al-Co oxide/Co0 inverse catalysts synthesis is devised by controlling the Al/Co ratio. The reduction of a precursor with a high Co/Al ratio in H2 atmosphere results in the creation of inverse supported catalysts. These catalysts feature an Al-Co oxide layer supported on Co0 surfaces, forming a specialized metal/metal oxide interface that offers abundant active sites while modulating the adsorption strength of intermediates. The formation of moderately bound H species plays a crucial role in the increased production of various intermediates. Notably, the augmented generation of *HCOO and *CH3, along with their coupling reactions, significantly enhances CO2 hydrogenation, leading to enhanced formation of ethanol. Amongst, the catalyst with a Co/Al ratio of 9:1 achieves high yields for methane (32,131 μmol/g), methanol (461 μmol/g), and ethanol (123 μmol/g). This study illuminates the interactions between metal and metal oxide in Co-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation and introduces a facile technique for engineering effective catalysts for such processes. coredata.dc:description: Inverse catalysts, characterized by their distinctive interfaces, demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity for CO2 conversion. This study explores the synthesis of an Al-Co oxide/Co0 inverse catalyst through the reduction of a Co-Al oxide with a high Co content, achieved by modulating the Co/Al ratio in the oxide precursor. The resulting inverse catalyst significantly enhances CO2 hydrogenation, yielding increased production of methane, methanol, and ethanol, with a notable amplification in ethanol output. Amongst, the catalyst with a Co/Al ratio of 9:1 achieves high yields for methane (32,131 μmol/g, methanol (461 μmol/g), and ethanol (123 μmol/g). To elucidate the structure and reaction mechanism, the inverse catalyst was also characterized using a suite of techniques. It is posited that the abundance of active sites on the inverse catalyst, coupled with its moderate H binding affinity, facilitates CO2 activation and conversion. This is particularly evident in the enhanced coupling of *HCOO and *CH3 intermediates, which promotes ethanol synthesis. This research not only sheds light on the interactions between metal and metal oxide within Co-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation but also proposes a facile method for crafting efficient catalysts for such processes.
